Overview:

Remington brought the hunting-rifle prowess, and a leading manufacturer of modular repeating rifles introduced us to the 308 Win platform. What emerged is a masterwork of game-dropping performance and hunt-specific features that will load any camp’s meat pole with unrivaled efficiency – the new Model R-25. An advanced, highly lethal blend of accuracy, fast followups and light recoil chambered for three of today’s most popular short-action hunting cartridges – 243 Win, 7mm-08 Remington and 308 Win. This rifle is everything varmint and predator hunters love about our R-15 in a beefed-up design that easily handles cartridges suitable for big-game hunting.
For peak accuracy, its precision-crafted 20" ChroMoly barrel is freefloated within the machined aluminum fore-end tube. Six longitudinal flutes forward of the gas block keep weight to a minimum and facilitate rapid heat dissipation. The barrel also features a recessed hunting crown to protect the rifling and aid in more consistent bullet flight. When it’s time to make the shot, the R-25’s ergonomic pistol-grip gives you unmatched control and rock-steady aim. As a whole, this rifle has a balanced, stable design that makes it deadly from the offhand position. True to our hunting market, the traditional two-stage trigger found on AR-platform rifles has been exchanged for a crisp, single-stage version that comes from the factory set at 4 1/2 to 5 lbs.
Its carefully tuned upper and lower are machined from rugged aluminum forgings. The entire gun is dressed in Mossy Oak® Treestand™ camo that makes it virtually invisible in the field. We included a 4-round magazine, and the R-25 is compatible with DPMS 308 Win-type magazines and accessories. front and rear sling swivel studs are installed.
Key Features:

    Semi-automatic AR-10-style rifle developed in conjunction with an industry leader in the category
    Free-floated button-rifled 0.680" Muzzle OD ChroMoly barrels with recessed hunting crown for superior accuracy
    Fluted barrel design reduces weight and promotes rapid barrel cooling
    Clean-breaking single-stage hunting trigger (factory set to 4.5-5lbs)
    Receiver-length Picatinny rail for adding optics and accessories
    Ergonomic pistol grip for rock solid aiming and control
    Front and rear sling swivel studs
    Legal for hunting in most states
    Compatible with aftermarket DPMS 308 Win Magazine Boxes
    Lockable hard case included

title: For Sale:  Firearms Trust for Class 3 Transfers
postcontent:
Greetings,



2.      What are the benefits of the  NFA Trust over the Corporate and individual form of ownership?

a.      No filing fee or annual fee

b.      There are NO requirements that the Trust be filed with the Secretary of State

c.       The trust documents and the assets of the trust remain private. 

d.      No CLEO signoff, no photos, no fingerprints and NO BEGGING the government for permission to exercise your Second Amendment rights! 

e.      The ability of anyone who is a trustee to be able to lawfully possess the weapons.

Avoid alot of hassle and extra work. I can draw up a Firearms Trust in your name, so you can transfer your Class 3 intem, Silencer / Machingun into it. You still have to get a $200.00 TAX stamp from the ATF. But a Firearms Trust allows you to Avoid alot of steps.

 Without a Trust you will need Fingerprints, Background Check, and signoff of local police in your county that they allow you to have the class 3 item. THe firearms trust acts like a corporation. But beware many people prepare general trusts which are not the same. They can deny your Application.

 I charge $100.00 compeleted Firearms Trust. Once you obtain the trust you can with you ATF forms and standard $200 ATF fee. Apply for you transfer of the Class 3 item.

 Less steps and I give you all info you'll need simple, fast & no confusion

Thanks

title: For Sale:  Noveske/LMT AR15 w/ LOTS of extras
postcontent:
Looking for some extra cash and the rifle is the only thing I can somewhat part with now. It has been nothing but reliable and has served as my partner in some sticky situations. The rifle has approximately 4-5k rounds through it with exception of 1 or 2 hiccups from running it dry AND using Wolf ammo . It is NOT a safe queen. It has been carried on duty, hunted, and competed with. It has killed many feral hogs, coyotes, and I even bagged a buck at 225 yards with the EOtech, so it is VERY accurate. It has lots of extras that will NOT be parted with. It all goes together or it doesn't go at all. I would like the extra cash but do not need it, so lowball offers will be ignored. If you can find something similar cheaper, please, by all means, buy it from them and save me the trouble of reading useless PM's. Next to the parts will be prices for reference. Obviously I didn't purchase everything at its regular price, but close. Everything Mapul is FDE. Here are the specs.

=$2,477 total for everything listed.

I'm sure there are extras laying around somewhere that I will try to include. Posted are older photos of the gun. Not much has changed other the lights and comps, both which DO NOT COME WITH THE GUN. I will take more pictures if requested. It will have an aftermarket flash hider (I can't remember what brand) and no light. Nice Gibbs No. 7 Jungle Carbine Enfield chambered in 7.62x51. Not a conversion from a .303. Original chambered Ishapore Enfield. Very good condition. 12 Round magazine. Here's the info from Gibb's sight:


Originally an extremely rare experimental design, the Australians designed the No. 7 for their jungle fighters in Burma. Now Gibbs Rifle Company has recreated this carbine using the modern, stronger 2A barreled action made from chrome vanadium steel. Chambered for the popular .308 Winchester, each No. 7 starts out as a hand selected, barreled 2A action, and is then cleaned, inspected and refurbished. The original wood is retained and reconfigured, and a flash hider with a bayonet lug has been added to recreate the original Jungle Carbine dimensions. The No. 7 Jungle Carbine is a short, powerful carbine, perfect for today’s collector, shooter and sportsman. Weight - 8 lbs., Bbl Length - 20”, OAL - 40”, Cal - .308 Winchester.

title: For Sale:  Model 1894 38-55 Winchester Rifle
postcontent:
Here is some info I was able to gather on this rifle.


This is a model '94, 38-55 with a short magazine. Serial number 387440 was manufactured March 4th, 1908. Even though the tang sight looks original to the gun (and it may have been put on the gun in 1908), the sight is approximately 20-years older than the gun is. I am intimately familiar with the early production Lyman tang sights (I collect them). The sight on your Model 1894 is the type found on the early Model 1873, 1876 and 1885 rifles. Those early sights are worth a fair bit more $$$ than the later ones.
Another thing you have going for it on value is that the round barrels were made for only 1 out of 11 of these types of rifles.

Payment for this rifle is US Postal Service money order or cash only

title: For Sale:  Model 1898 Krag Rifle
postcontent:
This Krag rifle has a serial number of 481208. Since the last Krag manufactured was serial number 481793 this means the this rifle was one of the last Krag’s made. In fact the number indicates the manufacture date was 1904.

It has a JSA 1903 Cartouche with firing proof behind triggerguard. Inspector JSA, J.S. Adams, 1890-1920. The letters NJ on the butt. This rifle may have been part of the New Jersey National Guard. It has the M1901 rear sight.

The website you got your manufacture date from is done by govt fiscal year. Fiscal year 1904 ran from July 1903 to June 1904, so the stock could very well be original to the rifle. Cartouches were done by calendar year, more than likely rifle had the latter 6 months of 1903 in which in which it could have been made.

This Model 1898 Rifle is in excellent shape. Weapons of this type and condition have sold on the internet for an excess of $1500.00.
Payment for this rifle is with US Postal Service money order or cash only

title: For Sale:  Model 1888 Springfield Trapdoor Rifle
postcontent:
All of the marks shown are perfectly normal and standard. In addition to the basic proofs [V P eaglehead P] [SWP 1890] and (P), the smaller marks and symbols are internal SA departmental codings, in some cases worker's initials, whose meaning has not been established. The bore grooves on this rifle looks very deep.

The Following Info I have gotten from folks who are supposed to be experts
The arm really is a Model 1884! "Model 1888", while it had SOME contemporary usage is MOSTLY a term of modern collector convenience, to indicate the final version of the rod-bayonet.
Now, there WERE 100 rifles (noted as having a "positive cam") actually marked "U.S. Model 1888" but they were experimental only - having a modification to the locking mechanism - they occur in the 4155xx range, and must not be confused with the normal rod-bayonet rifles, of which over 60,000 were produced.
Payment for rifle is with US Postal Service money order or cash

5 shot revolver, stainless steel finish, 2" barrel, hardwood grips.

This is a Model 1873 Springfield Trapdoor rifle. The 1873 Trapdoor was the first rifle to be chambered for the 45-70 cartridge.
The early 1873’s (up to 1877) had breech blocks case hardened and quenched in oil which gave them a black look. After 1877 case hardening process used water to quench which gave the brilliant silver color.

title: For Sale:  Model 1816 Eli Whitney 1834  *THIS MUSKET HAS BEEN SOLD
postcontent:
This musket started its life as a US model 1816, 69 caliber smoothbore flintlock  musket. The Whitneyville Armory was awarded two contracts to produce these muskets between 1822 and 1841. Some collectors call it the Whitney model 1822, as it had some slight improvements over the standard 1816 model. Other then some early muskets having a "browned" barrel, I could never figure out just what else was different. The 1834 date on the lock plate is the year it was made. It is the second of the three types of lock plates used.

This musket  has been converted to percussion, probably in the 1840s or 50s, by what is called the "Belgian Alteration". The brass part you see on the lock, is what remains of the flash pan. The NG and 50 on the butt plate  May be a unit marking, as many of the model 1816s were given to the states as militia allotments. The initials JM on the barrel are credited to Justin Murphy, an inspector at the armory. Many of these muskets saw service in the early days of the civil war.

At sometime, someone cut about a foot off the end of your barrel. It should be 42 inches long and have three bands holding it to the stock. After the civil war, all muzzle loaded firearms became obsolete, and there was thousands of them to be had. Many, were sold as cheap shotguns, and to make them easier to handle in the field, were shortened. Some were shortened by gunsmiths, and are nicely done, some were just sawed off. I actually saw one that was cut using a pipe cutter. It would be nice if it was not cut, it would be great if it was still an original flintlock. But all this is part of your muskets history, and our country's history as well. I'll bet there are not to many things you can buy today that will still be here in 175 years.
Payment is by US Postal Service money order only.
*THIS MUSKET HAS BEEN SOLD*

title: For Sale:  Forehand 12 Gauge Shotgun
postcontent:
The Forehand Arms Co. ( originally as Forehand and Wadsworth) was in business from the early 1870's until acquired by Hopkins & Allen sometime after the middle 1890's. They manufactured only (I believe ) low cost trade guns. There is probably no longer any serial number histroy available to determine exact age. In order to determine value the condition of the firearm has to be known. My guess, though, is that unless it is in very good condition the value is such that it would best be used as a decoration in the den. As you more than likely have read in my previous responses, refrain from shooting the decarbonized steel gun. Same was designed for low pressure loads of black-powder. The bulk of these 100 Y.O. guns had short chambers - please don't use modern ammo in them. Payment will be by US Postal Service money order only.
!
